title.value: Explorable Mesh Deformation Subspaces from Unstructured 3D Generative Models
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as provided by the user.
title.quote: Explorable Mesh Deformation Subspaces from Unstructured 3D Generative Models

extractions.description: This paper presents a novel method for exploring variations among a set of input 3D shapes using a 2D exploration space. The method constructs a mapping to a sub-space of a pre-trained generative model's latent space that optimizes the smoothness of interpolations. This allows for transferring these variations to high-quality meshes while avoiding detail loss from the generator's unstructured output.

type.justification: The paper demonstrates a practical method validated through experiments with 3D shapes, comparison with other methods, and quantitative metrics.
type.quote: We test our method using SP-GAN trained on ShapeNet as our shape generator G [Chang et al. 2015].

name.justification: The paper focuses on shape deformation, generative models, and 3D shape generation, which are key topics in the field of Computer Graphics.
The paper contributes to the field of 3D shape generation by proposing a new method for exploring 3D shape variations.
name.quote: Data-driven generative models have introduced revolutionary new capabilities to the practice of 3D shape design and exploration.

name.justification: SP-GAN is a state-of-the-art point cloud GAN used as the shape generator in the study.
name.quote: For our generator G, we employ SP-GAN [Li et al. 2021], a state-of-the-art point cloud GAN.

is_contributed.justification: SP-GAN is utilized in the study but is not introduced by the authors.
is_contributed.quote: For our generator G, we employ SP-GAN [Li et al. 2021], a state-of-the-art point cloud GAN.

is_executed.justification: SP-GAN was executed as part of the experiments in this paper.
is_executed.quote: We test our method using SP-GAN trained on ShapeNet as our shape generator G [Chang et al. 2015].

is_compared.justification: SP-GAN's results are compared with ShapeFlow and other models in the evaluation section.
is_compared.quote: We compare our results qualitatively and quantitatively with ShapeFlow. ... We specifically compare against ShapeFlow’s chair model, as other models were unavailable.

referenced_paper_title.value: SP-GAN: Sphere-Guided 3D Shape Generation and Manipulation
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for the SP-GAN model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For our generator G, we employ SP-GAN [Li et al. 2021], a state-of-the-art point cloud GAN.

name.justification: ShapeNet is used to train the SP-GAN model in the study.
name.quote: We test our method using SP-GAN trained on ShapeNet as our shape generator G [Chang et al. 2015].

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for the ShapeNet dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We test our method using SP-GAN trained on ShapeNet as our shape generator G [Chang et al. 2015].

name.justification: ShapeNet Manifold dataset is used for training and evaluation of the models in the study.
name.quote: We also use the ShapeNet Manifold dataset [Huang et al. 2018].

referenced_paper_title.value: Robust Watertight Manifold Surface Generation Method for ShapeNet Models
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for the ShapeNet Manifold dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We also use the ShapeNet Manifold dataset [Huang et al. 2018].

name.justification: PyTorch was used for implementation and optimization in the study.
name.quote: We use PyTorch and Adam for all optimization routines [Kingma and Ba 2014; Paszke et al. 2019].

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for PyTorch.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We use PyTorch and Adam for all optimization routines [Kingma and Ba 2014; Paszke et al. 2019].
